items.content_html:
Summary

PR #11945 changed the "official" name of the parameter from compareFunction to compareFn. However, parts of the article still mentioned compareFunction. This change ensures consistent naming; since Array.prototype.sort() in ECMA 262 refers to the parameter as comparefn, prefer compareFn to compareFunction.

Motivation

Referring to the same parameter using different names inhibits clarity.

Supporting details

Array.prototype.sort() in ECMA 262

Related issues

builds upon #11945

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Use the argument name compareFn consistently

items.content_html: Corrected et cetera (etc.) abbreviation.
items.title: Added a missing period after "etc."

items.content_html:
This PR adds formal syntax to those CSS data types for which formal syntax exists in webref (mostly, this is all except the "primitive" things like <string>).

It also tries to rationalize them to have formal syntax as an H2 before "Examples", as we do for properties.

I made bigger changes to the structure of https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/easing-function, since it seemed to be needed.
items.title: Add formal syntax for (some) CSS data types

items.content_html: this is not accurate per the menu element being semantically equivalent to the <ul> element - per HTML spec update from 2019 and browsers consistently exposing the element as a list - save for webkit which presently exposes the menu element as generic.
items.title: remove note about <menu> and role=menu being equivalent

items.content_html:
If you look at the AOM it literally says landmark if the header is a banner and section if it isn't, so saying it's not a sectioning element is wrong.

And, if you look at the original cern site, header is in body, and there is a head before body, so that was wrong too.

And the see also links to h1 to h6, not a topic on outlines, so removed that.

Summary

Motivation

items.content_html:
Summary

An introduction to basic MathML constructions.
This only introduces the "first steps" module but
more advanced topics may be added in the future.

Motivation

Chromium is expected to ship MathML soon, and it is likely that
developers read the documentation as suggested in the
Intent-to-ship thread [1]. Although we've been updating existing
MDN documentation it may still be difficult for people new to MathML
to learn about it. This PR addresses that by following the same
structure as HTML, CSS and JavaScript tutorials.

Supporting details

[1] https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/n4zf_3FWmAA

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Add MathML tutorial

items.content_html:
Summary

This PR is essentially to update the writing 'code example' guidelines in our writing style guide. Added the following as per @estelle's suggestion:
"In general, the code example should not only demonstrate the syntax of the feature and how it is used, but also highlight the purpose and situations in which a web developer might want or need to use the feature."

This PR also fixes some of the following issues in the writing style guide:

  • Removes the unnecessary indent characters >.
  • Changes some H4s to bullet points because we're recommending in the style guide to not go lower than three heading levels.
  • Changes some H4s to H3s by removing the parent H3.

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Fixes formatting in wsg and adds a code example guideline

items.content_html:
Classical for loops are error-prone (setting the right condition, not mixing indices…) and difficult to read when used to loop on all elements of an Array-like structure.

This PR changes some occurrences to use the modern for…of, or .forEach() in some occurrences.

Note that:

  • I use for…of if I don't need the index
  • I use .forEach() when I do, or on an object where for…of may not work.
  • There were a couple of cases where the loop copied an Array into a new one; I used Array.from() instead.
items.title: Avoid classical for when looping through all items of an Array-like object (part #2)

items.content_html:
Classical for loops are error-prone (setting the right condition, not mixing indices…) and difficult to read when used to loop on all elements of an Array-like structure.

This PR changes some occurrences to use the modern for…of, or .forEach() in some occurrences.

Note that:

  • I use for…of if I don't need the index
  • I use .forEach() when I do, or on an object where for…of may not work.
  • There were a couple of cases where the loop copied an Array into a new one; I used Array.from() instead.
items.title: Avoid classical for when looping through all items of an Array-like object
